passages.kjv_text: In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth. And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was  upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters. And God said, Let there be light: and there was light. And God saw the light, that it was good: and God divided the light from the darkness. And God called the light Day, and the darkness he called Night. And the evening and the morning were the first day.
passages.web_text: In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth. The earth was formless and empty. Darkness was on the surface of the deep and God’s Spirit was hovering over the surface of the waters. God said, “Let there be light,” and there was light. God saw the light, and saw that it was good. God divided the light from the darkness. God called the light “day”, and the darkness he called “night”. There was evening and there was morning, the first day.

passages.kjv_text: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. The same was in the beginning with God. All things were made by him; and without him was not any thing made that was made. In him was life; and the life was the light of men. And the light shineth in darkness; and the darkness comprehended it not.
passages.web_text: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. The same was in the beginning with God. All things were made through him. Without him was not anything made that has been made. In him was life, and the life was the light of men. The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness hasn’t overcome  it.

notes.context: Genesis opens with a majestic, poetic account of creation from a void. John's Gospel deliberately echoes this language, framing 'the Word' (Logos) as the divine agent of a new spiritual creation in Christ, present from the very beginning.
notes.reflection: Every day is a new creation, a personal 'let there be light.' How can we partner with the Word today to bring order, beauty, and goodness into our own small corners of the world?
